block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 31, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. All four children's lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles.

CHAPTER BOOKS
NEW MOON, by Stephenie Meyer. (Megan Tingley/ Little, Brown, $17.99.) A human and a vampire continue their love affair; a sequel to ''Twilight.'' (Ages 12 and up)

THE INVENTION OF HUGO CABRET, written and illustrated by Brian Selznick. (Scholastic, $22.99.) A novel ''in words and pictures''; an orphaned thief must decipher his father's last message. (Ages 9 to 12)
IMPULSE, by Ellen Hopkins. (McElderry, $16.99.) Three suicidal teenagers meet at a psychiatric hospital. (Ages 14 and up)
THE BOOK THIEF, by Markus Zusak. (Knopf, $16.95.) In Nazi Germany, a girl shares books with a Jewish man. (Ages 14 and up)
RULES, by Cynthia Lord. (Scholastic, $15.99.) Life with an autistic brother. (Ages 9 to 12)
THE HIGHER POWER OF LUCKY, by Susan Patron. Illustrated by Matt Phelan. (Richard Jackson/Atheneum, $16.95.) A 10-year-old plans to leave her small town. (Ages 9 to 11)
TWISTED, by Laurie Halse Anderson. (Viking, $16.99.) Caught spraying graffiti and sentenced to physical labor, a former nerd attracts his secret crush. (Ages 12 and up)
ON THE WINGS OF HEROES, by Richard Peck. (Dial, $16.99.) In World War II, a Midwestern boy looks up to his brother (who's fighting) and his dad (who's not). (Ages 9 to 12)
HATTIE BIG SKY, by Kirby Larson. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A young orphan inherits a Montana homestead in 1918. (Ages 9 to 12)
THE ASTONISHING LIFE OF OCTAVIAN NOTHING, by M. T. Anderson. (Candlewick, $17.99.) In 1700s Boston, a seemingly privileged black boy learns he's actually a slave. (Ages 14 and up)

PICTURE BOOKS
FANCY NANCY AND THE POSH PUPPY, by Jane O'Connor. Illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser. (HarperCollins, $16.99.) What kind of dog is best for a fancy girl? (Ages 4 to 7)
FANCY NANCY, by Jane O'Connor. Illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser. (HarperCollins, $15.99.) A girl takes her family out. (Ages 4 to 7)
FLOTSAM, by David Wiesner. (Clarion, $17.) The things that wash up on the beach; a story in pictures. (Ages 4 to 7)
SOMEDAY, by Alison McGhee. Illustrated by Peter H. Reynolds. (Atheneum, $14.99.) A mother imagines her child's future. (Ages 4 to 8)
MAHALIA MOUSE GOES TO COLLEGE, by John Lithgow. Illustrated by Igor Oleynikov. (Simon & Schuster, $17.99.) A rodent earns her Harvard degree. (Ages 4 to 8)
PIRATES DON'T CHANGE DIAPERS, by Melinda Long. Illustrated by David Shannon. (Harcourt, $16.) To recover treasure, a crew of pirates first has to baby-sit. (Ages 4 to 8)
DOG, by Matthew Van Fleet. Photography by Brian Stanton. (Paula Wiseman/Simon & Schuster, $14.99.) An interactive look at 20 breeds. (Ages 3 to 5)
NOT A BOX, written and illustrated by Antoinette Portis. (HarperCollins, $12.99.) Imagination turns a young rabbit's cardboard box into anything but. (Ages 3 to 6)
TODAY I WILL FLY!, written and illustrated by Mo Willems. (Hyperion, $8.99.) Piggie is determined to fly, even though Gerald the elephant tells him it's impossible. (Ages 4 to 8)
LIBRARY LION, by Michelle Knudsen. Illustrated by Kevin Hawkes. (Candlewick, $15.99.) A lion obeys the library rules until there's good reason not to. (Ages 5 to 8)

PAPERBACK BOOKS
ELDEST, by Christopher Paolini. (Knopf, $12.99.) Eragon in the land of elves; Book 2 in the Inheritance trilogy. (Ages 12 and up)
IT's NOT EASY BEING MEAN, by Lisi Harrison. (Little, Brown, $9.99.) Actually, it's easier than you might think. A ''Clique'' novel. (Ages 14 and up)
ERAGON, by Christopher Paolini. (Knopf, $9.95.) A boy and a dragon must navigate a world of dark powers. (Ages 12 and up)
MAXIMUM RIDE: SCHOOL'S OUT -- FOREVER, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $6.99.) Who's trying to kill Max and her flying friends? (Ages 9 to 12)
TWILIGHT, by Stephenie Meyer. (Megan Tingley/Little, Brown, $8.99.) The new girl falls in love with a vampire. (Ages 12 and up)
MUGGLENET.COM'S WHAT WILL HAPPEN IN HARRY POTTER 7, by Ben Schoen et al. (Ulysses, $13.95.) Predictions from a leading fan Web site. (Ages 8 and up)
BRIDGE TO TERABITHIA, by Katherine Paterson. (HarperCollins, $6.99.) Unlikely friends rule an imaginary land. (Ages 9 to 12)
HEART OF GLASS, by Zoey Dean. (Little, Brown, $9.99.) Caught on a celebrity's estate, two girls have to organize a charity fashion show; an ''A-List'' novel. (Ages 15 and up)
THE STORY OF THE EASTER BUNNY, by Katherine Tegen. Illustrated by Sally Anne Lambert. (HarperCollins, $6.99.) How the Easter Bunny learned his trade. (Ages 3 to 8)
UGLIES, by Scott Westerfeld. (Simon Pulse, $7.99.) In a dystopian world, beauty is mandatory. (Ages 12 and up)

SERIES
MAGIC TREE HOUSE, by Mary Pope Osborne. Illustrated by Sal Murdocca. (Stepping Stone/Random House, hardcover and paperback.) Children travel in time. (Ages 6 to 9)
JUNIE B., FIRST GRADER, by Barbara Park. Illustrated by Denise Brunkus. (Stepping Stone/Random House, hardcover and paperback.) Adventures in school. (Ages 4 to 8)
THE SISTERHOOD OF THE TRAVELING PANTS, by Ann Brashares. (Delacorte, hardcover and paperback.) Four friends share magical pants. (Ages 12 and up)
SEPTIMUS HEAP, by Angie Sage. (Tegen/HarperCollins, hardcover.) Lost at birth, a boy fulfills his destiny as a wizard. (Ages 9 and up)
HARRY POTTER, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, hardcover and paperback.) Trouble at Hogwarts. (Ages 10 and up)
INTERNET GIRLs, by Lauren Myracle. (Amulet/Abrams, hardcover and paperback.) Social life, via instant messages. (Ages 14 and up)
A SERIES OF UNFORTUNATE EVENTS, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, hardcover only.) The poor Baudelaires. (Ages 10 and up)
WARRIORS: THE NEW PROPHECY, by Erin Hunter. (HarperCollins, hardcover only.) Cat warriors fight for survival. (Ages 10 to 14)
THE ALEX RIDER ADVENTURES, by Anthony Horowitz. (Philomel/Speak, hardcover and paperback.) A boy spy follows in his father's footsteps. (Ages 10 and up)
D'lacey's dRAGONs, by Chris d'Lacey. (Orchard/Scholastic, hardcover and paperback.) Clay figurines come to life. (Ages 9 to 12)
